citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There are three expired vials of rabies vaccines in the refrigerator that is used for medication storage. When asked if the
facility has any other vials of rabies vaccine that is being used or available the facility representative stated these are the
only vials on hand. The vials have an expiration date stamp of 09 July 2024. When reviewing the medical records for the
dogs in the kennel 2 adult dogs (#2444 and #2442) were administered a rabies vaccine on 10 August 2024 and 15
September 2024 which is past the expiration date of the vials on hand.
Medications being used past the expiration date have unknown efficacy and potency; thus, they may no longer be
efficacious for the labeled indications of use. Correct by ensuring that the facility is using the appropriate methods to
prevent and control diseases.
Correct by 22 October 2024 and from this day forward

The facility is not following the program of veterinary care for vaccinations. The Program of Veterinary Care currently
prescribes dogs will be vaccinated for rabies at 16 weeks of age, booster at 1 year, and every 3 years going forward. The
program currently prescribes dogs will be vaccinated for leptospirosis at 11 weeks of age, 16 weeks of age, and annually
going forward.
3 adult dogs are not up to date on their rabies vaccine as they did not receive the 1-year booster:
-#6247
-#7972
-#7971
2 poodles approximately 22 weeks of age are not up to date on their rabies or leptospirosis vaccines:
-#3697
-#3689
2 dachshunds approximately 24 weeks of age are not up to date on their rabies or leptospirosis vaccines:
-#5235
-#5237
Failure to follow the preventative care schedule for vaccinations in the Program of Veterinary Care does not ensure the
dogs are receiving appropriate protection against contagious and deadly diseases such as distemper, parvo,
leptospirosis, and rabies which can lead to illness and discomfort to the dogs. The facility must follow the vaccination
schedule approved by the attending veterinarian in the Program of Veterinary Care to protect the dogs from deadly or
contagious diseases.
Correct by 5 November 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There are three expired vials of rabies vaccines in the refrigerator that is used for medication storage. When asked if the 
facility has any other vials of rabies vaccine that is being used or available the facility representative stated these are the 
only vials on hand. The vials have an expiration date stamp of 09 July 2024. When reviewing the medical records for the 
dogs in the kennel 2 adult dogs (#2444 and #2442) were administered a rabies vaccine on 10 August 2024 and 15 
September 2024 which is past the expiration date of the vials on hand.  
 
Medications being used past the expiration date have unknown efficacy and potency; thus, they may no longer be 
efficacious for the labeled indications of use. Correct by ensuring that the facility is using the appropriate methods to 
prevent and control diseases. 
 
Correct by 22 October 2024 and from this day forward 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility is not following the program of veterinary care for vaccinations. The Program of Veterinary Care currently 
prescribes dogs will be vaccinated for rabies at 16 weeks of age, booster at 1 year, and every 3 years going forward. The 
program currently prescribes dogs will be vaccinated for leptospirosis at 11 weeks of age, 16 weeks of age, and annually 
going forward.  
3 adult dogs are not up to date on their rabies vaccine as they did not receive the 1-year booster: 
-#6247 
-#7972 
-#7971  
2 poodles approximately 22 weeks of age are not up to date on their rabies or leptospirosis vaccines: 
-#3697 
-#3689 
2 dachshunds approximately 24 weeks of age are not up to date on their rabies or leptospirosis vaccines:  
-#5235 
-#5237

Failure to follow the preventative care schedule for vaccinations in the Program of Veterinary Care does not ensure the 
dogs are receiving appropriate protection against contagious and deadly diseases such as distemper, parvo, 
leptospirosis, and rabies which can lead to illness and discomfort to the dogs. The facility must follow the vaccination 
schedule approved by the attending veterinarian in the Program of Veterinary Care to protect the dogs from deadly or 
contagious diseases.  
 
Correct by 5 November 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative. 
 
 n
